DOC.HEAD: American Soldier Shot to Death Near Defense Forces Headquarters
DOC.BYLINE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Panama calling incident a provocation, says three Panamanians wounded; picks up 9th pvs, `The television...' ^By ELOY O. AGUILAR
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. soldier was fatally shot Saturday night as he and three other American servicemen tried to flee a crowd of Panamanian troopers and civilians, a U.S. Southern Command spokesman reported. The Panamanian Defense Forces said Sunday that the U.S. servicemen had fired several shots at the military headquarters of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, wounding three Panamanians, including a soldier and a 1-year-old girl. U.S. officials said the Americans were unarmed. U.S. and Panamanian troops went on alert after the incident, the most serious in a series of confrontations between the two forces. American troops in battle gear could be seen around Fort Clayton, and tanks were heading toward the base. Several unidentified helicopters flew over the city shortly after midnight. A U.S. spokesman, Col. Ronald Sconyers, said four off-duty American soldiers in civilian clothes were stopped by about 40 civilians and five Defense Forces troopers as they were driving by military headquarters. The spokesman said the crowd tried to pull the Americans out of the car, and as the U.S. soldiers drove off shots were fired at the car, wounding one of the Americans. He said the other U.S. servicemen were not injured. The wounded American was taken to the U.S. military's Gorgas Hospital where he died, Sconyers said. He did not identify the victim pending notification of his relatives. The Defense Forces made no mention of the American casualty in a statement issued at 4 a.m. Sunday. It said a car with U.S. license plates broke through checkpoints, drove past the Defense Headquarters and fired several shots at it, wounding three Panamanians. The 1-year-old, Elin Bethancourt, was wounded in the left arm, the Defense Forces said. Lt. Col. Arnulfo Castrejon, the duty officer at the time, called the incident ``a provocation against the life and property of our people.'' Civilians said Panamanian troopers condoned off the area surrounding the Defense Forces headquarters. The television channel of the U.S. Southern Command announced that a ``Delta'' alert was in effect, restricting U.S. military personnel to their bases. That alert was ordered during the October revolt by a small group of Defense Forces personnel. Since May, there have been several confrontations between Panamanian and U.S. forces in Panama that included shouting matches, but no shooting. A Noriega-organized paramilitary force, the Dignity Battalions, have demonstrated and tried to block recent U.S. maneuvers. In a recent letter, the U.S. high command told the Panamanian military that any action against U.S. personnel would be considered an action by the Defense Forces. A government official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Noriega, who was declared Panama's chief of government Friday, was in the western province of Chiriqui late Saturday. In appointing Noriega chief executive, the rubber-stamp legislature said the action was necessary because Panama was in a ``state of war'' with the United States. It based the state-of-war declaration on severe ecnomic sanctions imposed on Panama in an effort to force Noriega to step down. Noriega had been Panama's de facto ruler as Defense Forces chief. The general, who is under indictment on drug-trafficking charges in the United States, thwarted an Oct. 3 coup attempt when loyal troops came to his support after he was trapped and held hostage by the rebels for several hours. At least 10 of the rebellious officers and soldiers who launched the October coup were killed, either in fighting or after they surrendered. Noriega has denied the U.S. drug charges and says Washington's efforts to oust him are an attempt to avoid complying with the 1977 Panama Canal Treaties. The accords turn the waterway over to Panama at the end of the century. After the October coup he claimed the United States was behind the revolt, but Washington denied that. Some of the 12,000 American troops stationed in Panama had blocked streets near Defense Forces headquarters but they did not become engaged in the conflict.
